awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Food Sovereignty and Self-Governance--Inuit Role in Managing Arctic Marine Resources
awd_abstract_narration:
Inuit possess a distinct and sophisticated knowledge of the Artic ecosystem which is crucial to its balance and sustainability. As first inhabitants, stewards, and traditional users intimately tied to the Arctic environment, the discrete status, rights, and interests of Inuit as Indigenous Peoples are affirmed in a number of legally binding treaties, as well as other international human rights instruments and domestic laws. Inuit authorities, organizations, and communities are central to the establishment and maintenance of effective mechanisms for safeguarding this ecologically and culturally unique region.

The Food Sovereignty and Self-Governance Project aims to advance understanding of Inuit self-governance of marine resources deemed crucial for Inuit food security. This includes exploring how Inuit co-management systems support food sovereignty objectives - outcomes that are essential for supporting human rights of Inuit communities. This project will examine the role Inuit communities in Alaska and Canada play in managing these resources as co-equal partners with their counterparts in federal, state, and local government agencies. The results derived from the research will prove valuable to other Arctic federal governments collaborating with Indigenous communities to achieve objectives related to the environmental, social, and ecological well-being of the Arctic. 


The project's overarching goals are to:

1) Synthesize the existing legal frameworks providing for Inuit self-governance by evaluating applicable legal authorities in the United States (U.S.) and Canada;
2) Determine how existing Inuit self-governance approaches operate in practice by examining four co-management case studies as examples of approaches to food sovereignty. This will provide a comprehensive understanding of the social, political, and institutional parameters affecting implementation of key legal frameworks;
3) Understand whether and how Inuit self-governance systems support food sovereignty by comparing food sovereignty objectives against both these legal frameworks and observation of the implementation of those systems in practice; and
4) Disseminate Project findings to Inuit, state/territorial, national, and international leaders with the goal of supporting and driving improvements to systems providing for collaborative management of Arctic marine resources in the face of rapid ecological change.

The Project Team will take a two-tiered analytical approach to address these goals: (1) doctrinal legal research that evaluates legal and institutional frameworks; and 
(2) socio-legal analysis through case-studies.   The legal research will examine relevant laws, regulations, and policies at all levels of government, building a framework essential to understanding how Arctic collaborative governance functions in theory.  The case studies will take the next step - moving from how these governance systems should work to how they operate in practice - and, ultimately, how they could be improved in a manner which optimizes outcomes for food sovereignty, human rights, and resource sustainability. Case studies conducted in partnership with those participating in co-management regimes, will focus on Walrus and Salmon in Alaska and Char and Beluga in the Inuvialuit Settlement Region of Canada. Current partners of this project include:

(1)	The Eskimo Walrus Commission
(2)	The Fisheries Joint Management Committee
(3)	The Inuvialuit Game Council

Organizations advising this project include both the Association of Village Council Presidents and the Inuit Circumpolar Council Canada.

Project researchers conducting the case study analysis will follow a "co-production of knowledge" approach, in which no one person's information and knowledge is assigned greater inherent value than another's. Researchers with utilize Indigenous Knowledge and social science methodologies. The project will intimately engage with Inuit who play a role in natural resources management in the U.S. and Canadian Arctic under each case study, through focus groups, semi-directive interviews and discussions'all guided by input provided by an expert Advisory Committee. 

The Project will advance the state of knowledge on how Inuit self-governance approaches support Inuit food sovereignty objectives and resource sustainability. With a combined focus on the United States and Canada, the Project will enable comparative analysis of legal and institutional structures, practices, and perceptions to facilitate critical evaluation of Inuit self-governance over marine resources as embodied in co-management regimes. This research will also be useful for other Arctic nations that are working with Indigenous peoples to achieve the environmental, social, and ecological well-being of the Arctic.

por.por_cntn:
For thousands of years, Inuit have thrived, rooted in values that shape the relationships they hold with everything within the Arctic ecosystem. These values—including respect, collaboration, and sharing—all aid in supporting healthy and harmonious relationships and communities. These values are incorporated in hunting, fishing, gathering, and preparing foods and are a core element of Inuit culture. Inuit food systems require an understanding of the distinct connection between food security, environmental health, and food sovereignty. Without food sovereignty, Inuit cannot achieve food security.

The Food Sovereignty and Self-Governance: Inuit Role in Managing Arctic Marine Resource (FSSG) is an Inuit led project, developed through partnerships across Alaska and the Inuvialuit Settlement Region (ISR) of Canada and with the Environmental Law Institute. The project is rooted in a co-production of knowledge (CPK) approach, utilizing methodologies from Indigenous Knowledge and science.  

The Project has advanced the understanding of Inuit self-governance and management practices deemed crucial for Inuit food security and produced tools valuable to other governments collaborating with Indigenous peoples to achieve objectives related to the environmental, social, and ecological well-being of the Arctic. In 2020, the Inuit Circumpolar Council Alaska (ICC Alaska) published a landmark report called Food Sovereignty and Self-Governance: Inuit Role in Managing Arctic Marine Resources. The 144-page report is co-authored with Inuit from Alaska and the ISR) and examines Inuit management and co-management to distill lessons that transcend geographic boundaries. Most important, the report offers Inuit perspectives on these systems. To achieve true co-management, reflective of the Inuit way of life, Inuit perspectives, summaries, and communications about legal and political frameworks of management and co-management were necessary.

The outcomes highlight both challenges and solutions. For example, the resulting work addresses different management and research approaches. Inuit have a holistic understanding of the interconnections between all elements within an ecosystem. In contrast, single-specie approaches to management practiced by scientific and non-Inuit governmental institutions is one of the significant barriers to  co-management systems that equitably include Inuit, and often harmful to all species and ultimately whole ecosystems. In 2015, the ICC identified six dimensions that make up food security: Availability, Inuit Culture, Decision-Making Power and Management, Health and Wellness, Stability, and Accessibility. The FSSG work confirmed that crucial tools related to policy, co-management, and knowledge are required to maintain food security and that use of these tools must be driven by Inuit food sovereignty.

The FSSG project utilized four case studies to illustrate the interconnected elements necessary for food sovereignty and successful management needed to support Inuit food security. In Alaska, two cases involved salmon and walrus management. In the Inuvialuit Settlement Region of Canada, the project examined char and beluga management. The methodology utilized Indigenous Knowledge; social science; and legal research with the focus on Inuit perspectives and knowledge to ensure equity; the opportunity for co-production of knowledge (equitably bringing together Indigenous Knowledge and science); and the durability of Inuit security in relation to their food systems.

The FSSG assessment found that the policies and approaches impeding Inuit food sovereignty are particularly evident within top-down approaches and imposition of international policies and agreements. These frameworks tend to threaten or stifle rather than enhance food security and food sovereignty. Federal, territorial, and state laws, policies, and regulations do not entirely capture the diverse and comprehensive nature of Inuit food systems, from the emotional and spiritual connection that Inuit have to hunting, harvesting, and fishing, or being part of the environment. Such systems fail to account for the fact that Inuit relationships with animals have important economic, social, cultural, and spiritual values and dimensions.

The tools provided, such as technical and summary reports, offer many insights from Inuit on components and approaches that need to be considered to apply a co-production of knowledge approach – describing both challenges and what works. The work puts forward transformative recommendations that, when implemented, will support Inuit food sovereignty and aid in safeguarding the Arctic environment, and sustaining the culture and way of life for all Inuit.

This project has positively impacted the limited base of knowledge, theory, and research on Inuit management and co-management, particularly for researchers and policymakers presently conducting work in the Arctic. The project reports underscore the profound relationship between Inuit as distinct peoples and their surrounding traditional homelands and environment. Their intimate understanding of the interrelated nature of the all species, both Arctic marine and terrestrial elements, has culminated over centuries into a sphere of Indigenous Knowledge unmatched by others. This Knowledge has been illuminated though the work conducted and sheds light on a wide array of issues facing not only the Arctic region but beyond as well. The interaction of adaptive management, Indigenous Knowledge, and legal analysis provides a template to incorporate different spheres of knowledge in the future and solutions for improved, sustainable management and co-management of unique resources.
